Experts say that robust reporting of Scope 3 emissions is critical to giving the rule teeth; by contrast, a company‚Äôs direct emissions (Scope 1) and those associated with its purchase and use of energy (Scope 2) usually account for just a fraction of its overall footprint. While the GOP attacks the SEC‚Äôs statutory authority to require Scope 3 disclosures, BlackRock is pushing changes that
could render those requirements almost meaningless.

A subtler form of opposition to the SEC rule is coming from another quarter: investment firms, most prominently BlackRock. These companies say they support a new disclosure rule but are quietly fighting its key provisions.

But the firm‚Äôs comments then recommend substantial changes, including expanding a proposed ‚Äúsafe harbor‚Äù that would shield companies from liability for inaccurate or incomplete emissions disclosures. BlackRock also advocated for a ‚Äúcomply or explain‚Äù approach ‚Äúwhich allows issuers to either disclose material Scope 3 emissions or explain why certain emissions categories are not relevant to the issuer or not subject to reasonable estimation.‚Äù

While acknowledging the importance of assessing Scope 3 emissions, BlackRock‚Äôs comments assert that the methodologies for measuring them are currently limited and still evolving, and that ‚Äúwith the broader adoption of reporting standards, datasets, and methodologies, they will improve meaningfully further.‚Äù

Public Citizen‚Äôs Shrago argues that requiring large companies to begin producing reasonable estimates of their emissions is precisely what will accelerate that improvement. ‚Äú[Measuring Scope 3 emissions] will only get easier and cheaper with a rule requiring all companies to do it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe challenge right now is that there just isn‚Äôt standardized data.‚Äù

BlackRock also suggests that the final SEC rule should be aligned with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-Related Disclosures (TCFD) ‚Äî an industry-led group of which BlackRock is a member. The TCFD framework, which BlackRock uses in its own climate risk reporting, recommends disclosing Scope 3 emissions ‚Äúwhere appropriate.‚Äù
